I'm a single lesbian mother.

I was like, the truth is I have HIV.

A good day really is me talking and seeing my daughter, who just turned 18 on July 2, because I never thought that I would live to see her turn 18.
Like I said, I was diagnosed when she was eight.
My dream would really be to see her walk down the aisle in college.
A friend of mine told me, I probably would be no more good, I'd probably be speechless, I'd probably be passed out.

And it's moments like that that makes me want to live, you know.
I know my life is like, okay, I'm 24, I have full-blown AIDS, I'm living on my own, no family support, no anybody, but it's made me open-minded.
Like, I see things in a different way and I think having this made me a better person, to tell you the truth.
I've had so many conversations with people who don't use protection, who don't think it's important.
Because I can talk about myself today, I let them know that I'm positive and they say, wow, you look so good.

My motto has always been, if I can save one life while I'm here, then my job is done.
